events.subtitle: Experience the vibrant culture of Atlanta

home.hero_subtitle: Experience the premier art museum in the Southeast.
home.about_p1: Founded in 1905 as the Atlanta Art Association, the High Museum of Art has evolved into the premier art institution in the Southeastern United States. We are custodian to a permanent collection of spanning seven dedicated curatorial departments including African Art, American Art, and one of the nation's leading collections of Southern and African American folk art. Our campus is an architectural landmark, featuring buildings designed by Pritzker Prize-winning architects Richard Meier (1983) and Renzo Piano (2005), which together offer over 312,000 square feet of gallery space dedicated to making art accessible to all.
home.stats_verified: Verified via Institutional Records & AIA 2024 Audit

featured.subtitle: Discover over 18,000 extraordinary works
featured.see_more: See all of these and more at the High Museum of Art

visitor.subtitle: Plan your next inspiring visit
visitor.marta_hint: Just across from the Arts Center Station via MARTA.
visitor.arch_text1: The High is the only museum in the world to feature major permanent buildings by two Pritzker Prize-winning architects. Richard Meier's 1983 signature white building was cited by the
visitor.arch_text1_end: as one of the ten best works of American architecture in the 1980s.
visitor.arch_text2: The 2005 expansion by Renzo Piano added three new buildings, tripling the museum's capacity and introducing a revolutionary 'light scoop' roof system that filters natural light into the skyway galleries.
visitor.tickets_desk: Tickets also available at the front desk.
visitor.second_sundays_text_beginning: Admission is free on the second Sunday of each month.
visitor.second_sundays_text_end: visitors engage with our programs annually, as reported by institutional attendance records.
visitor.resource1: Architectural history and AIA 1991 citation verified by
visitor.resource2: Renzo Piano expansion details (2005) provided by
visitor.resource3: Transportation and MARTA access confirmed via
visitor.resource4: Attendance and community impact data sourced from the

footer.disclaimer: This website was developed as part of a FBLA (Future Business Leaders of America) Competitive Event: Exploring Website Design.

reviews.text: Great museum...They have curated it with such care...I love the folk art level and all of the surrealist and spiritual artwork.
reviews.author: Candice H.

reviews.text: A wonderful place to go to be inspired and soak in some of the most amazing art in Georgia...buy a yearly membership...You just might see something you might not normally get to experience and it might change your heart and mind in the process.
reviews.author: Brian C.

reviews.text: This is a top notch art museum. Highly recommend.
reviews.author: Brad D.

reviews.text: A great experience as always. I make a point of attending their exhibitions when ever I'm in town. Highly recommend this current showing. It will not disappoint.
reviews.author: Janna K.

artworks.name: Ibibio Artist, Ekpo Society, Nigeria
artworks.description: A 20th-century wood and pigment mask representing the Ekpo society's spiritual authority. Such artifacts served as moral law enforcers within the community. (Source: Ibibio Cultural Archives)
artworks.metadata: 20th Century • Wood, Pigment • African Art Dept.

artworks.name: Igbo Artist, Nigeria
artworks.description: A vibrant representation of the water spirit Mami Wata, blending indigenous beliefs with global influences to symbolize wealth and power. (Source: African Arts Journal)
artworks.metadata: 20th Century • Mixed Media • African Art Dept.

artworks.name: Andrew Wyeth
artworks.description: A powerful technical study of two antique coats hanging in Wyeth's studio, once belonging to the Quaker artist Howard Pyle. (Source: High Museum Records)
artworks.metadata: 1975 • Watercolor on Paper • American Art Dept.

artworks.name: Henry Ossawa Tanner
artworks.description: A masterful exploration of light and human spirit by the first African American painter to gain international acclaim. (Source: Smithsonian Archives)
artworks.metadata: 1923 • Oil on Canvas • American Art Dept.

artworks.name: Hella Jongerius
artworks.description: Part of the "Technicolor" series, this work challenges industrial color standards through artisanal textile techniques. (Source: Jongeriuslab)

artworks.name: Hella Jongerius
artworks.description: An investigation into monochromatic depth and texture, bridging the gap between mass production and individual craft. (Source: Design Museum)
artworks.metadata: 2009 • Wool and Cotton • Decorative Arts Dept.

artworks.name: Alfred Sisley
artworks.description: A seminal work of French landscape painting that paved the way for the Impressionist movement. (Source: High Museum Records)
artworks.metadata: 1894 • Oil on Canvas • European Art Dept.

artworks.name: Aimé-Jules Dalou
artworks.description: A bronze sculpture created between 1898 and 1899, demonstrating the artist's focus on the dignity and labor of the working class. (Source: High Museum Records)

artworks.name: Henry Church
artworks.description: A stark, evocative work by one of the most significant self-taught artists of the 20th century. (Source: New Georgia Encyclopedia)
artworks.metadata: 1939 • Poster Paint on Cardboard • Folk Art Dept.

artworks.name: Nellie Mae Rowe
artworks.description: Rowe's vibrant geometric patterns represent the ecstatic spiritual visions of the Southern self-taught tradition. (Source: High Museum Archives)
artworks.metadata: 20th Century • Mixed Media • Folk Art Dept.

calendar.typically_closed: Typically closed on Mondays for gallery maintenance.
calendar.open_today: Open today. General Admission includes all collections and exhibitions.
calendar.ga_desc: Explore our permanent collection featuring over 18,000 works of art spanning multiple centuries and artistic movements. General admission includes access to all galleries and exhibitions.
calendar.closed_today_desc: The museum is closed today in observance of the holiday.

membership.title: BECOME A MEMBER
membership.subtitle: Join more than 30,000 households supporting the premier art museum in the Southeast. Enjoy unlimited access, exclusive events, and the satisfaction of supporting the arts in Atlanta.
membership.official_source: Official Source: High Museum of Art - Join & Membership Records (2024 Audit)
membership.ready_to_join: Ready to join our community? Enter your details below for a real confirmation email.
membership.received: Your application for the membership has been received successfully.
membership.sent_to: A confirmation email has been sent to:
membership.thank_you: Thank you for supporting the High.
membership.cancel_desc: Enter your details to permanently cancel your membership.

benefits.title: Unlimited Admission
benefits.text: Unlimited daytime admission to the permanent collection and most special exhibitions.

benefits.title: Free Parking
benefits.text: Free daytime parking in the Woodruff Arts Center garage (when available).

benefits.title: Discounts
benefits.text: Member discounts at the museum shop, café, classes, and public programs.

benefits.title: Early Access
benefits.text: Presale tickets and early access for High Frequency Fridays and Friday Jazz.

benefits.title: Member Events
benefits.text: Invitations to members-only previews, tours, and special social events.

benefits.title: Reciprocal Access
benefits.text: Free admission to hundreds of museums across North America (select levels).

levels.name: Student
levels.description: Lowest-cost option with core benefits for full-time students.

levels.name: Individual
levels.description: Best value for solo visitors; includes admission, parking, and guest passes.

levels.name: Dual/Family
levels.description: Covers two adults plus free admission for children/grandchildren (17 & under).

levels.name: Contributing
levels.description: Adds more guest passes, a caregiver pass, and wider reciprocal museum access.

levels.name: Patron
levels.description: Includes monthly exhibit tours, higher discounts, and expanded perks.

levels.name: Director's Circle
levels.description: VIP experiences like curator-led tours, private events, and behind-the-scenes access.
